title: The Entertainer

musicalLanguage.description: Scott Joplin's most famous rag, published in 1902. The Entertainer is built on the contrast between a syncopated, playful right hand melody and a steady left hand 'oom-pah' pattern. Joplin marked it 'Not fast' — ragtime is not about speed, it's about the tension between the off-beat melody and the on-beat bass. That rhythmic tug is what makes it swing.
musicalLanguage.structure: Classic ragtime AABB form. This arrangement covers the A section (the intro theme) — the melody everyone recognizes. Two 8-bar phrases: the first states the theme, the second repeats with slight variation and a stronger ending.
keyMoments: Measures 1-2: The iconic opening — the syncopated pickup figure that everyone knows. D4-E4-C5-E5, landing on the downbeat of measure 2.
Measures 3-4: The melody climbs to E5 with syncopation, while the left hand keeps steady oom-pah.
Measures 5-6: The melody descends through a chromatic passage — E5, D5, C5 — with eighth-note syncopation.
Measure 8: The first phrase ends with a resolution to C4 — a small cadence.
Measures 9-16: Second pass with variation — the melody adds chromatic passing tones.
teachingGoals: Syncopation: the right hand plays BETWEEN the left hand beats. This rhythmic offset is the soul of ragtime.
Left hand oom-pah: bass note on beats 1 and 3, chord on beats 2 and 4. Metronomic. Unwavering.
Independence: hands must operate on different rhythmic tracks without pulling each other off time.
Dynamics through touch: make the melody sing above the accompaniment through finger weight, not volume.
Tempo discipline: Joplin said 'It is never right to play ragtime fast.' Honor the groove.
styleTips: NOT FAST. Joplin wrote this instruction on his scores. If it feels rushed, slow down.
The left hand is a clock. The right hand dances around it. Never let the right hand speed up the left.
Slight accent on the syncopated notes — make the listener feel the off-beat emphasis
Keep the left hand quieter than the right. The bass and chords are the frame, not the picture.
Think of it as stride piano in embryo — the precursor to jazz piano

measures.rightHand: R:q D4:e E4:e C5:e E4:e C5:e E5:e
measures.leftHand: C3:q E3:e G3:e C3:q E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: The iconic opening figure. The right hand starts with a rest on beat 1 — the melody enters off the beat. D4-E4-C5-E4-C5-E5: a zigzag climb that everyone recognizes. Left hand plays C major chord tones in an oom-pah figure.

measures.leftHand: G2:q B2:e D3:e G2:q B2:e D3:e
measures.teachingNote: The melody settles: D5 down to G4 through a graceful descent. The left hand shifts to G major pattern — the V chord. This two-bar unit (m1-2) IS the Entertainer.

measures.rightHand: R:q D4:e E4:e C5:e E4:e C5:e E5:e
measures.leftHand: C3:q E3:e G3:e C3:q E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: The opening figure repeats — same melody, same charm. In ragtime, repetition is structural. The listener expects it, and the familiarity creates comfort.

measures.leftHand: G2:q D3:e G3:e G2:q D3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: Similar descent but with a rest mid-phrase — a breath before landing on G4. The rest gives the melody shape.

measures.rightHand: R:q D4:e E4:e C5:e E4:e C5:e E5:e
measures.leftHand: C3:q E3:e G3:e C3:q E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: Third time with the opening figure — but this time it leads somewhere new. The repetition sets up the contrast in the next bars.

measures.leftHand: F3:q A3:e C4:e F3:q A3:e C4:e
measures.teachingNote: The melody changes course — E5 descending to C5, then climbing back to E5. Left hand moves to F major (IV chord). The harmony shifts for the first time, adding color.

measures.leftHand: G2:q B2:e D3:e G2:q B2:e D3:e
measures.teachingNote: A chromatic descent: D5, C5, B4, A4 — smooth and elegant. Then B4 bounces back up, setting up the resolution. Left hand returns to G.
Resolution — C5 held for two beats, then silence. The first 8-bar phrase is complete. The left hand confirms C major with a rising figure. The rest is structural: it separates the two halves.

measures.rightHand: R:q D4:e E4:e C5:e E4:e C5:e E5:e
measures.leftHand: C3:q E3:e G3:e C3:q E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: The theme returns for the second pass. Same melody — but the listener knows it now. Recognition creates pleasure. This is ragtime's secret: structured repetition with subtle variation.

measures.leftHand: G2:q B2:e D3:e G2:q B2:e D3:e
measures.teachingNote: Same descent as measure 2. The repeat grounds the listener.

measures.rightHand: R:q D4:e E4:e C5:e E4:e C5:e E5:e
measures.leftHand: C3:q E3:e G3:e C3:q E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: The figure once more — building toward the new ending.

measures.rightHand: E5:e D5:e C5:e A4:e G4:q C5:q
measures.leftHand: F3:q A3:e C4:e G2:q B2:e D3:e
measures.teachingNote: The variation: instead of the usual descent, the melody tumbles quickly through E5-D5-C5-A4 in eighth notes, lands on G4, then leaps up to C5. More motion, more energy. Left hand: F major to G major — a IV-V setup.

measures.leftHand: C3:q E3:e G3:e C3:q E3:e G3:e
measures.teachingNote: New melodic material: D5 to E5 rising, then a quick turn back down through C5 to A4. The second pass is more adventurous — the melody explores.

measures.leftHand: G2:q B2:e D3:e G2:q B2:e D3:e
measures.teachingNote: B4 stepping up to D5, then dropping an octave-like distance to G4. A wide melodic shape. Left hand holds steady on G.

measures.leftHand: C3:q E3:e G3:e F3:q A3:e C4:e
measures.teachingNote: A rising scale figure: E4 through B4 in even steps. The left hand moves C to F — I to IV — adding harmonic momentum. Building to the final bar.
The ending: C5 held, then silence. Cleaner than the first ending — more definitive. Left hand: C3-G3-C4, a rising fifth that confirms the tonic. The A section is complete.

source: Arrangement: AI Jam Session. Based on Scott Joplin's The Entertainer (1902).
